headline: Loss of peripheral vision could be signs of glaucoma, optometrist warns
summarized_story:
Amarachi OkehAn optometrist, Dr. Oluchi Ubani has warned that the loss of peripheral vision could be a sign of the onset of glaucoma, noting that such a development should be promptly checked.
Peripheral vision loss occurs when people can’t see objects unless they’re right in front of them.
According to the optometrist, the state of peripheral vision can gives hints on the general condition of the sight.
That is our peripheral vision.
“However, when glaucoma starts taking away your peripheral vision, you will discover that you may not be able to see what is happening by the side except you fully turn your head.

headline: 17-year-old girl diagnosed with premature menopause shares experience
summarized_story:
Lara AdejoroAnna Timson was just 17-years-old when she was diagnosed with early menopause.
But Anna was initially diagnosed with a high level of FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and immediately put on the pill.
She regularly uses The Daisy Network, which is a UK charity offering information, advice, and support for women diagnosed with premature menopause.
Anna recalls how her sister’s pregnancy in 2018 ‘opened up a lot of the trauma’ that she’s been through.
“I told him straight away that I couldn’t have children; I wanted to be honest with him,” she said.

headline: Twitter’s suspension in Nigeria worrisome, media must remain vigilant — US
summarized_story:
The United States, US, Consulate in Lagos has described as deeply worrisome, the suspension of Twitter by the Federal Government.
Claire Pierangelo, US Consul-General, made the remarks, Wednesday, at a programme, entitled “Conversation on Press Freedom, Freedom of Expression and Civic Space in Nigeria,” in Lagos.
She said the government’s intention to introduce registration requirements for social media platforms, banning or restricting social media with threats of prosecution, undermined the human rights and fundamental freedom of Nigerians.
She said: “Nigerian government’s ongoing suspension of Twitter and stated intent to introduce registration requirements for other social media platforms is deeply worrisome.

headline: Lagos Assembly adopts report to stop houses for ex-governors, others
summarized_story:
The Lagos State House of Assembly has approved the report of its committee on establishment which recommended the reduction of pensions to former governors and other affected officials by 50 percent.
The committee also expunged the provision of houses in Abuja and Lagos for former governors as stipulated in an earlier law operated by the state.
The report showed a reduction in the number of vehicles to be made available to former governors and their deputies.
Speaker of the House, Mudashiru Obasa, suggested that former governors should get two vehicles (a car and a van) instead of three as recommended by the committee.
However, Obasa argued that it should be left at 50 percent, especially as the report had recommended the removal of houses and reduced other benefits.

headline: FG threatens to sack striking doctors
summarized_story:
From Fred Ezeh, AbujaFederal Government has threatened to sack resident doctors who withdrew their services nationwide since August 2 over alleged poor conditions of service.
The threat was contained in a letter by the Permanent Secretary, Federal Ministry of Health, Abdullaziz Abdullahi, and addressed to the doctors through their umbrella body, the National Association of Resident Doctors (NARD).
Government said it would, probably, leverage on court judgment delivered by Justice Oluwakayode Olosegbe of Enugu branch of the National Industrial Court (NIC) to take its administrative actions if the doctors failed to return to work.
It, thus, reminded the striking doctors that the industrial court judgment indicated that they have no right to embark on strike for certain reasons.
NARD President, Uyilawa Okhuaihesuyi, confirmed to Daily Sun that the letter from Federal Ministry of Health was received, yesterday, and their lawyers were working on the matter.

headline: Ex-Nigerian Dictator, Babangida Rules Out Tinubu, Atiku, Says Nigeria’s Next President Should Be In Their 60s
summarized_story:
Former Nigerian military dictator, Ibrahim Badamasi Babangida, also known as IBB has said Nigeria’s next president should be in his 60s, ruling out two major aspirants, a former vice president, Atiku Abubakar and a former governor of Lagos State, Bola Tinubu, from the 2023 presidential run.
Though he did not make a direct reference to the duo, IBB, during an interview with Arise TV, suggested that individuals in their 60s should be the focus of Nigerians as potential presidential candidates in 2023.
From available records, the next general election will be held in 2023, and by that time, Atiku should be 77, while Tinubu, who marked his 68th birthday in March, would have turned 70 years.
Babangida further said one of the reasons Nigeria has not developed or achieved the dreams of its founding fathers was because Nigerians no longer believed in the future of their own country.
“That is a person, who is very versed in economics and is also a good politician, who should be able to talk to Nigerians and so on.

headline: Corruption in Nigeria worse under civilian leaders than military rulers, says IBB
summarized_story:
Ibrahim Badamasi Babangida (IBB), former military head of state, says corruption in Nigeria is worse under civilian leaders than under military rulers.
The former military head of state said people who steal public money under civilian administrations are on the streets walking free.

“Till today, unfortunately, the political class are not really into this seriously and say how do we build a nation,” he said.

headline: I Couldn’t Put Barcelona At Risk: Laporta Defends Messi’s Exit
summarized_story:
Barcelona’s negotiations with Lionel Messi are over and the striker is considering other offers, the club’s president Joan Laporta said on Friday.
Laporta said in a press conference he was not prepared “to put the club at risk” by renewing Messi’s contract, with Barca facing huge financial problems ahead of the start of La Liga.
“We could not accommodate Messi’s contract,” said Laporta, who was re-elected as club president in March.
Laporta said Barca could have registered Messi by agreeing to the deal but insisted it was a risk he was not prepared to take.
“We were not prepared to put the club at risk in this way,” said Laporta.

Universal Pictures, Will Packer Productions and Mo Abudu’s EbonyLife have picked up the adaptation rights to the Bloomberg article “The Fall of the Billionaire Gucci Master,” about the Instagram influencer Ramon Abbas, also known as Ray Hushpuppi, @hushpuppi, Hush or the Billionaire Gucci master.
The Bloomberg story by Evan Ratliff detailed claims by authorities that Nigerian-born Abbas perfected a simple internet scam and laundered millions of dollars.
An untitled action thriller project, set up at Universal Pictures, follows a contested auction for the property.
AdvertisementWill Packer and James Lopez will produce through their Will Packer Productions and Abudu will produce for EbonyLife Studios.

headline: ‘We Were Saints’: IBB Says Corruption in Nigeria Worse Now Than When He Was in Power – Arise News
summarized_story:
Former Nigerian military president, Ibrahim Babaginda, says the depth of corruption under Nigeria’s democratic dispensation is such that his regime will be seen as one of saints.
In an exclusive interview on Friday, Babaginda told ARISE News that talk of corruption during his regime cannot be compared with “facts on ground now.”Watch the video for more…

headline: IBB: We Annulled June 12 Elections to Avoid Violent Coup
summarized_story:
A former Nigerian military leader Ibrahim Babangida says there would have been a violent coup if the 1993 June 12 elections weren’t annulled.
Mr Babaginda stated this on Friday in an exclusive interview with ARISE News.
He said, “if it had materialised, there would have been a coup d’etat which could have been violent.”According to the former military dictator, the coup would have given room for more instability in the country, but noted that the overthrow did not happen due to the “Maradonic way we handled you guys in the society.”Watch the exclusive interview for more.

headline: IBB: Tyranny of Nigerian Elites Hindering Implementation of 2014 National Conference
summarized_story:
The tyranny of Nigerian elites has been hindering the implementation of resolutions reached at the 2014 national conference, former head of state, Ibrahim Babaginda has said.
The former Nigerian military leader said this during an exclusive interview with ARISE News and faulted the regular calls for national conferences but insisted on the implementation of the conventions already carried out.
Mr Babangida also in a veiled manner called for restructuring and the full autonomy of the local governments.
Watch the interview for more.

headline: Jailed Former SA President Jacob Zuma Admitted to Hospital Ahead of Corruption Trial
summarized_story:
South Africa’s jailed former president Jacob Zuma has been admitted to a hospital for medical observation on Friday, the government’s Correctional Services department said.
As a former head of state Zuma is treated at a military facility, the authorities said.
A routine observation at the prison prompted authorities to take him to an outside hospital for further examination, a Correctional Services statement said.
It added that as a former president, Zuma’s healthcare needs required the involvement of South African Military Health Services.
Zuma, 79, was jailed for defying a constitutional court order to give evidence at an inquiry investigating high-level corruption during his nine years in office until 2018.

headline: Olympics Expels Two Belarus Coaches Over Athlete’s Removal
summarized_story:
Belarus says Ms Timanovskaya was removed from the national team because of her emotional state.
Ms Timanovskaya said two coaches came into her room and told her to pack her bags immediately, ready to return home.
At the airport, Ms Timanovskaya showed officers a translated plea for help on her phone in an effort to avoid being put on a plane home.
But Ms Timanovskaya insists that she is “not a political girl” and just wants to focus on her sporting career.
The sprinter told the BBC she wanted to return to Belarus, but that it was too dangerous at the moment.
